title: Issue View Modal with Tabbed Editing
description:
Expand the existing `openDescription()` modal into a full issue view with three editable tabs: Description, Design, and Acceptance Tests. All three fields should be viewable and editable within the modal.

**Why it's needed:**
The current modal only shows the description field, but issues in Beads have richer content including design notes and acceptance criteria. Users need to:
- View all issue context without leaving the current view
- Edit any field without navigating to a separate page
- Quickly switch between related content (description ‚Üí design ‚Üí acceptance)
- Maintain context while reviewing different aspects of an issue

This reduces friction for issue refinement and review workflows.

**Usage Examples:**
1. Developer opens issue modal, reads description, switches to Acceptance tab to understand done criteria
2. Product owner edits acceptance tests directly in modal during backlog refinement
3. Designer updates the Design tab with UI notes without losing their place in the table
4. During standup, team reviews all three tabs of a complex issue to clarify scope

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Refactor `openDescription()` modal to `IssueViewModal` component
- Implement tab navigation with three tabs: "Description", "Design", "Acceptance"
- Each tab displays corresponding field content with Markdown rendering (read mode)
- Each tab has an "Edit" button or toggle to switch to edit mode
- Edit mode shows textarea with raw Markdown content
- Save and Cancel buttons in edit mode
- Save triggers API update for the specific field
- Optimistic update with error rollback
- Preserve tab state when switching between read/edit modes
- Modal header shows issue ID and title (editable title as stretch goal)
- Close modal with Escape key, click outside, or X button
- Keyboard navigation between tabs (arrow keys or Ctrl+Tab)
- Unsaved changes warning if user attempts to close with edits pending

**Required Unit Tests:**
- Modal renders with three tabs visible
- Clicking each tab displays correct field content
- Description tab shows issue description with Markdown rendered
- Design tab shows issue design field with Markdown rendered
- Acceptance tab shows issue acceptance field with Markdown rendered
- Edit button switches tab to edit mode with textarea
- Textarea contains raw Markdown content for editing
- Save button triggers API call with updated content
- Cancel button reverts to read mode without saving
- Optimistic update shows new content immediately
- Failed save shows error and reverts content
- Close attempts with unsaved changes shows confirmation
- Escape key closes modal (when no unsaved changes)
- Empty fields display appropriate placeholder/empty state
design:
**Modal Layout:**
- Width: 600-800px (responsive, narrower on mobile)
- Height: auto with max-height and scroll
- Header: Issue ID badge + Title (left), Close X button (right)
- Tab bar: immediately below header, full width
- Content area: below tabs, scrollable if content exceeds height
- Footer: contextual (shows Save/Cancel in edit mode)

**Tab Design:**
- Horizontal tabs: "Description" | "Design" | "Acceptance"
- Active tab: bold text, underline or background highlight
- Inactive tabs: regular weight, muted color
- Tab icons optional: üìù Description, üé® Design, ‚úÖ Acceptance

**Read Mode:**
- Rendered Markdown content with proper styling (headers, lists, code blocks)
- "Edit" button positioned top-right of content area (pencil icon + "Edit")
- Empty state: "No [description/design/acceptance criteria] provided. Click Edit to add."

**Edit Mode:**
- Full-width textarea replacing rendered content
- Textarea height: min 200px, auto-grows with content
- Monospace font for Markdown editing
- Footer bar with: "Cancel" (secondary button), "Save" (primary button)
- Optional: simple Markdown toolbar (bold, italic, list, code)

**Unsaved Changes:**
- Visual indicator when edits pending (dot on tab, asterisk in title)
- Confirmation dialog on close attempt: "You have unsaved changes. Discard?"
- Options: "Discard", "Keep Editing"

**Responsive:**
- Mobile: modal becomes full-screen or near-full
- Tabs remain horizontal but may use icons only on very narrow screens
- Textarea remains usable with adequate height
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Issue modal displays three tabs: Description, Design, and Acceptance
- [ ] Each tab renders its content as formatted Markdown
- [ ] User can switch to edit mode on any tab and modify the content
- [ ] Saving updates the issue field and returns to read mode
- [ ] Canceling edit discards changes and returns to read mode
- [ ] User is warned before closing modal with unsaved changes
- [ ] Empty fields display helpful placeholder text with prompt to add content

title: Assignee Management and WIP Visualization
description:
Implement comprehensive assignee management including assignment/reassignment capabilities, assignee-based filtering, and visualization of work-in-progress per team member.

**Why it's needed:**
Team coordination requires knowing who is working on what:
- Individuals need personal task lists
- Leads need to identify overloaded team members
- Teams need to balance workload distribution
- High WIP per person correlates with context switching costs and slower delivery

Currently, assignee may be a field but lacks dedicated UX for management and visualization.

**Usage Examples:**
1. Developer filters to "Assigned to me" to see their personal work queue
2. Team lead views WIP-per-person chart, notices Alice has 8 items while Bob has 2
3. During standup, lead reassigns items from overloaded developer to balance load
4. New team member is assigned their first items via dashboard interface

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Create `AssigneeSelector` component for assigning/reassigning issues
- Dropdown with team member list (populated from existing assignee values + manual entry)
- Support unassigned state
- Integrate into issue detail view and bulk actions
- Create `AssigneeFilter` in quick filters sidebar
- Show all assignees with issue counts
- Include "Unassigned" as filterable option
- Create `WIPByAssigneeChart` component
- Bar chart showing active item count per assignee
- "Active" = open or in_progress status
- Sort by count (highest first) or alphabetically (configurable)
- Color-code bars based on WIP thresholds (configurable: warning at X, critical at Y)
- Tooltip shows list of items on hover

**Required Unit Tests:**
- AssigneeSelector displays all unique assignees from data
- AssigneeSelector allows selecting an assignee
- AssigneeSelector allows clearing assignment (unassigned)
- Assignment change triggers API update with correct value
- AssigneeFilter shows correct counts per assignee
- AssigneeFilter includes unassigned with correct count
- Clicking assignee filter filters issues correctly
- WIPByAssigneeChart renders correct bar for each assignee
- WIPByAssigneeChart counts only active statuses (open, in_progress)
- WIPByAssigneeChart sorts by count correctly
- WIP threshold coloring applies correctly
- Bulk assignment updates multiple issues
design:
**Assignee Selector:**
- Dropdown/combobox with search
- Shows existing team members as options
- Avatar/initials next to names
- Clear button for unassigning
- "Add new assignee" option for first-time names

**WIP by Assignee Chart:**
- Horizontal bar chart (names on Y-axis, count on X-axis)
- Bar color: green (normal), yellow (warning threshold), red (critical)
- Configurable thresholds in settings (default: warning=5, critical=8)
- Tooltip on hover shows list of issue titles
- Click bar to filter dashboard to that assignee

**Assignee Quick Filter:**
- Section in filter sidebar
- List of assignees with counts
- Avatar/initials for visual scanning
- "Unassigned (X)" at top or bottom of list

**Personal View Shortcut:**
- "My Work" button/link prominently placed
- One-click filter to current user's assignments
- Requires knowing current user (could be configurable setting)
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] User can assign or reassign issues to team members from the issue detail view
- [ ] User can filter issues by assignee using quick filters
- [ ] Dashboard displays WIP count per team member as a bar chart
- [ ] Team members with high WIP are visually highlighted (color-coded thresholds)
- [ ] Clicking on an assignee in the chart or filter shows only their issues
- [ ] Unassigned issues can be filtered and viewed separately

title: Throughput Run Chart with Trends
description:
Implement a line chart showing the number of work items completed per time period (daily/weekly) with configurable rolling average trend lines (7-day, 14-day, 30-day).

**Why it's needed:**
The current throughput display shows raw daily counts, but this doesn't reveal delivery trends. Teams need to understand:
- Is delivery capability improving, declining, or stable over time?
- What's the sustainable delivery rate for forecasting?
- Did a process change positively or negatively impact throughput?
- Is the daily variation normal or concerning?

A rolling average smooths out daily noise and reveals the underlying trend, which is essential for capacity planning and continuous improvement.

**Usage Examples:**
1. Team lead reviews 30-day throughput trend before sprint planning to set realistic commitments
2. After implementing pair programming, team tracks whether 14-day average is increasing
3. Manager notices 7-day average dropping and investigates (holidays? blockers? attrition?)
4. During retrospective, team compares this month's trend line to previous month

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Create `ThroughputRunChart` component using existing charting library
- X-axis: dates (auto-scale based on selected date range)
- Y-axis: count of items completed (closed/done status)
- Primary data series: daily/weekly completed count as bars or line
- Overlay trend lines: 7-day, 14-day, 30-day moving averages (toggleable)
- Calculate moving average: sum of last N periods / N (handle edges gracefully)
- Time period toggle: Daily vs Weekly aggregation
- Trend line toggle controls in chart legend or settings
- Visual indicators for trend direction (up arrow green, down arrow red, flat yellow)
- Tooltip on hover showing: date, raw count, each moving average value
- Integrate with existing date range filter
- Handle sparse data gracefully (days with zero completions)

**Required Unit Tests:**
- Chart renders with correct data points for daily aggregation
- Chart renders with correct data points for weekly aggregation
- 7-day moving average calculated correctly (test with known data)
- 14-day moving average calculated correctly
- 30-day moving average calculated correctly
- Moving average handles edge cases (fewer days than window size)
- Zero-completion days are included (not skipped)
- Toggling trend lines shows/hides respective lines
- Tooltip displays correct values on hover
- Chart updates when date range filter changes
- Chart handles empty data set (no completions in range)
design:
**Chart Layout:**
- Full-width card with title "Throughput Trend"
- Chart height: 300-400px
- Legend below or to the right of chart

**Visual Elements:**
- Daily counts: vertical bars (subtle color) or points with connecting line
- Moving averages: smooth lines in distinct colors
  - 7-day: blue
  - 14-day: green  
  - 30-day: orange
- Trend direction indicator: small arrow icon next to current average value in legend

**Controls:**
- Toggle buttons for Daily/Weekly in chart header
- Checkboxes or clickable legend items to show/hide each trend line
- Current values displayed in legend (e.g., "7-day avg: 3.2 items/day ‚Üë")

**Tooltip:**
- Appears on hover over any data point
- Shows date, raw count, and all active moving average values
- Clean, readable format with clear labels

**Empty/Sparse States:**
- No data: "No completed items in selected date range" message
- Sparse data: Show available points, moving averages adapt to available data
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Chart displays daily or weekly throughput counts for the selected date range
- [ ] 7-day, 14-day, and 30-day moving average trend lines can be toggled on/off
- [ ] Hovering over data points shows detailed tooltip with date and values
- [ ] Chart clearly indicates whether throughput trend is increasing, stable, or decreasing
- [ ] Chart responds to dashboard date range filter
- [ ] Chart handles periods with zero completions without breaking

title: Service Level Expectation (SLE) Monitor
description:
Implement a configurable Service Level Expectation system that allows teams to define cycle time targets (e.g., "85% of bugs should be closed within 48 hours") and visualizes actual performance against these targets with proactive breach alerts.

**Why it's needed:**
Flow metrics are valuable but not actionable without targets. SLEs transform cycle time data into commitments teams can make to stakeholders:
- "We resolve critical bugs within 24 hours, 90% of the time"
- "Features are typically delivered within 2 weeks"

Without SLEs, teams can't answer "are we meeting expectations?" and stakeholders can't rely on delivery timelines. SLEs also enable proactive alerts when items are aging toward a breach.

**Usage Examples:**
1. Team defines SLE: "85% of P0 bugs closed within 24h" ‚Äî dashboard shows current performance is 78%, highlighting the gap
2. Support manager sees 3 bugs approaching their 24h SLE deadline and escalates
3. Product owner shares SLE performance report showing 92% of features delivered within sprint
4. During retro, team notices P2 bug SLE dropped from 90% to 75% and investigates

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Create `SLEConfiguration` component for defining SLEs
- SLE definition includes: name, filter criteria (type, priority, labels), time target (hours/days), confidence level (percentage)
- Store SLE configurations in localStorage (or Beads if schema supports)
- Create `SLEMonitor` component displaying all configured SLEs
- For each SLE: calculate actual percentile from historical data, compare to target
- Visual indicator: green (meeting/exceeding), yellow (within 5% of target), red (missing)
- Create `SLEAtRiskList` showing active items approaching their SLE deadline
- Calculate "time remaining" for each active item based on its applicable SLE
- Sort at-risk items by urgency (least time remaining first)
- Integrate SLE status into issue cards/rows (optional badge showing SLE status)

**Required Unit Tests:**
- SLE configuration saves and loads correctly
- SLE with type filter correctly selects matching issues
- SLE with priority filter correctly selects matching issues
- SLE with combined filters works correctly (AND logic)
- Percentile calculation returns correct value for known dataset
- SLE status correctly determined: meeting (green), at-risk (yellow), breaching (red)
- At-risk calculation correctly identifies items approaching deadline
- At-risk list sorted by urgency (least time remaining first)
- SLE handles edge cases: no matching issues, all issues meeting SLE
- Time remaining calculation accounts for item's current age
design:
**1 SLE Configuration Modal:**
- Form with fields: SLE Name, Issue Type (dropdown), Priority (multi-select), Target Time (number + unit), Target Percentile (slider 50-99%)
- Example preview: "85% of P1 bugs within 48 hours"
- Save/Cancel buttons, validation for required fields

**SLE Monitor Card:**
- Grid or list of configured SLEs
- Each SLE shows: name, target (e.g., "85% within 48h"), actual performance (e.g., "82%"), status indicator
- Circular progress or gauge visualization comparing actual to target
- Click to expand and see underlying data/issues

**At-Risk Panel:**
- Prominent placement (top of dashboard or dedicated section)
- List of items with: title, ID, applicable SLE, time remaining, status
- Color coding: yellow (<25% time remaining), red (<10% or overdue)
- Click item to view details

**Visual Indicators:**
- Status colors consistent with dashboard theme
- Clear iconography: checkmark (meeting), warning triangle (at-risk), X (breaching)
- Percentage display with decimal precision (e.g., "87.3%")
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Test
- [ ] User can create SLE definitions with filter criteria, time target, and percentage target
- [ ] Dashboard displays actual performance percentage for each configured SLE
- [ ] SLEs are visually indicated as meeting (green), at-risk (yellow), or breaching (red)
- [ ] At-risk panel shows active work items approaching their SLE deadline
- [ ] At-risk items are sorted by urgency with time remaining displayed
- [ ] SLE configurations persist across browser sessions

title: Flow Efficiency Tracker
description:
Implement a flow efficiency metric that calculates and visualizes the ratio of active work time versus total cycle time (active + waiting), showing overall efficiency percentage and trends over time.

**Why it's needed:**
Flow efficiency reveals how much time work spends actively being worked on versus waiting (blocked, queued, deferred). Typical teams have 15-40% flow efficiency, meaning 60-85% of cycle time is waste (waiting).

This metric:
- Shifts focus from "work faster" to "reduce wait time"
- Identifies where work stalls in the process
- Provides a single health metric for flow
- Enables before/after comparison for process improvements

**Usage Examples:**
1. Team discovers flow efficiency is 20%, meaning items wait 4x longer than they're worked on
2. After reducing handoffs, team tracks flow efficiency improving from 22% to 35%
3. Manager compares flow efficiency across different issue types (bugs vs features)
4. During retro, team identifies "blocked" status as the biggest efficiency killer

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Define active statuses: `in_progress` (configurable, could include others)
- Define waiting statuses: `open`, `blocked`, `deferred` (configurable)
- Calculate time spent in each status from issue history (requires status change timestamps)
- Note: This may require Beads schema/API to expose status change history
- If history unavailable, calculate based on current state and created date as approximation
- Create `FlowEfficiencyGauge` component showing overall percentage
- Create `FlowEfficiencyTrend` chart showing efficiency over time (weekly rolling)
- Create `FlowEfficiencyByStatus` breakdown showing time in each status
- Calculate per-issue efficiency for completed items
- Show distribution of flow efficiency across items (histogram)

**Required Unit Tests:**
- Active time calculated correctly from status history
- Wait time calculated correctly from status history
- Flow efficiency percentage calculated correctly (active / total)
- Handles issues with no active time (0% efficiency)
- Handles issues with no wait time (100% efficiency)
- Overall efficiency aggregates correctly across multiple issues
- Trend calculation groups by correct time periods
- Status breakdown sums to 100% of cycle time
- Fallback calculation works when history unavailable
- Per-issue efficiency calculated and displayed correctly
design:
**Flow Efficiency Gauge:**
- Prominent card/widget placement
- Circular gauge or large percentage display
- Color coding: red (<25%), yellow (25-50%), green (>50%)
- Comparison to previous period: "‚Üë 5% from last month"

**Efficiency Trend Chart:**
- Line chart with flow efficiency percentage on Y-axis
- Time on X-axis (weekly data points recommended)
- Reference lines at key thresholds (25%, 50%)
- Tooltip shows week dates and efficiency value

**Status Time Breakdown:**
- Horizontal stacked bar or donut chart
- Segments for each status, sized by total time spent
- Active statuses in green tones, waiting in yellow/red tones
- Legend with status names and percentages

**Per-Issue Efficiency:**
- Optional column in table view
- Small efficiency badge on issue cards
- Histogram showing distribution of flow efficiency across completed items
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Dashboard displays overall flow efficiency as a percentage
- [ ] Flow efficiency trend is visualized over time (weekly or configurable period)
- [ ] Breakdown shows time distribution across different statuses (active vs waiting)
- [ ] Flow efficiency is color-coded to indicate health (red/yellow/green thresholds)
- [ ] Individual completed issues show their flow efficiency metrics
- [ ] Configuration allows customizing which statuses count as "active" vs "waiting"

title: Interactive Chart Exploration
description:
Enhance all dashboard charts with interactive capabilities: zoom, pan, click-to-drill-down, and bidirectional linking between chart points and the issue table.

**Why it's needed:**
Current charts display data but don't enable exploration. Users see a concerning data point but can't easily identify which issues it represents. Interactive charts transform metrics from "informative" to "actionable" by:
- Connecting visual outliers directly to specific work items
- Allowing focused analysis of time ranges or data subsets
- Enabling exploratory data analysis workflows
- Reducing context switching between charts and tables

**Usage Examples:**
1. User sees outlier point on cycle time scatterplot, clicks it, table filters to show that issue
2. User notices spike on CFD, clicks that region, sees the 5 items that caused it
3. User zooms into last 2 weeks on throughput chart for detailed daily analysis
4. User hovers over histogram bar, sees list of issues in that bucket

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Implement zoom functionality for time-series charts (CFD, Throughput)
- Mouse wheel or pinch to zoom, drag to pan
- Reset zoom button to return to full view
- Implement click handlers for all chart data points
- Scatterplot points: click filters table to that single issue
- Histogram bars: click filters table to issues in that range/bucket
- CFD areas: click filters table to issues in that status at that time
- Implement hover state improvements for all charts
- Enhanced tooltips with more context (issue title preview, not just ID)
- Visual highlight of hovered element
- Implement bidirectional linking
- Clicking a table row highlights corresponding point(s) on visible charts
- Selection state persists until cleared
- Add "Show in table" button to chart tooltips

**Required Unit Tests:**
- Zoom in increases chart detail (axis range decreases)
- Zoom out decreases chart detail (axis range increases)
- Pan moves visible range without changing zoom level
- Reset zoom returns to original axis ranges
- Scatterplot point click triggers filter with correct issue ID
- Histogram bar click triggers filter with correct range values
- Hover displays enhanced tooltip with issue details
- Table row click highlights corresponding chart point
- Multiple chart types respond to same selection state
- Selection clear resets both chart highlights and table filters
design:
**Zoom/Pan Controls:**
- Zoom: mouse wheel (desktop), pinch (touch)
- Pan: click and drag on chart background
- Reset button: positioned in chart corner, appears only when zoomed
- Visual indicator of zoom level or "zoomed" state

**Click Interaction:**
- Cursor changes to pointer over clickable elements
- Clicked element shows selection state (ring, highlight, etc.)
- Selection persists until clicking elsewhere or explicit clear
- Multi-select with Cmd/Ctrl+click for comparing multiple points

**Enhanced Tooltips:**
- Larger tooltip area with structured content
- Issue ID, title (truncated), key metrics
- "View in table" link/button
- Tooltip positions intelligently (doesn't overflow viewport)

**Bidirectional Highlighting:**
- When chart point selected, corresponding table row highlighted (background color)
- When table row clicked, chart point highlighted (pulsing animation or ring)
- Clear selection button in both contexts

**Visual Feedback:**
- Smooth transitions for zoom/pan operations
- Hover states: subtle scale increase or glow effect
- Selection states: distinct from hover (different color or style)
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] User can zoom in/out on time-series charts using mouse wheel or touch gestures
- [ ] User can pan zoomed charts by clicking and dragging
- [ ] Clicking a point on any chart filters the issue table to related issues
- [ ] Hovering over chart elements displays detailed tooltips with issue information
- [ ] Selecting an issue in the table highlights its corresponding point(s) on charts
- [ ] Reset button returns zoomed charts to their default view

title: Custom Date Range Filtering
description:
Implement a global date range filter with an interactive date picker and preset quick-select options that filters all dashboard data to the specified time period.

**Why it's needed:**
All time-based metrics require flexible date filtering to be useful:
- Sprint analysis: "Show me the last 2 weeks"
- Quarterly review: "Show Q1 vs Q2 performance"
- Incident response: "What happened this week?"
- Excluding anomalies: "Skip the holiday period"

Without date filtering, metrics include all historical data which may not reflect current team performance or may be skewed by outlier periods.

**Usage Examples:**
1. Team selects "Last 14 days" preset for sprint review
2. Manager picks custom range Jan 1 - Mar 31 for quarterly report
3. User selects "Last 30 days" to establish current cycle time baselines
4. Tech lead excludes December holiday period when analyzing throughput

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Create `DateRangeFilter` component with dual-calendar picker
- Start date and end date selection with validation (start <= end)
- Quick presets: Today, Last 7 days, Last 14 days, Last 30 days, Last 90 days, This month, Last month, This quarter, This year, All time
- Custom range option opens calendar picker
- Selected range displayed prominently in dashboard header
- Filter state stored in global context/state management
- All chart components subscribe to date range context
- All table/list components filter by date range
- Date range syncs to URL query parameters
- Consider both "created" and "completed" date filtering modes

**Required Unit Tests:**
- Date picker allows valid range selection
- Date picker prevents invalid ranges (end before start)
- Each preset calculates correct date range
- Preset "Last 7 days" returns correct start/end dates
- Preset "This month" returns correct start/end dates
- Preset "This quarter" returns correct start/end dates
- Filter state updates propagate to chart components
- Filter state updates propagate to table components
- URL updates with date range parameters
- Page load with date range params applies filter correctly
- All time preset removes date filtering
- Filter handles timezone correctly
design:
**Filter Placement:**
- Dashboard header, right side (prominent but not obtrusive)
- Shows current selection: "Last 14 days" or "Jan 1 - Jan 31, 2024"
- Click to open filter dropdown/popover

**Dropdown Design:**

- Right side: dual calendar for custom range
- Clear visual separation between presets and custom
- Apply/Cancel buttons for custom range

**Calendar Picker:**
- Two side-by-side month calendars
- Click to select start, click again for end
- Selected range highlighted across both calendars
- Month/year navigation arrows
- Clear selection button

**Visual Feedback:**
- Selected preset highlighted in list
- Custom range shows specific dates in header
- Active filter indicator (subtle badge or color) when not "All time"

**Responsive:**

- Presets remain easily tappable (adequate touch targets)

title: All Epics View
description:
TEST Implement a dedicated table view for epic-type issues, separated from the main "All Issues" table. Epics should be excluded from the standard issues table and displayed in their own section with enhanced parent-child relationship visibility.

**Why it's needed:**
Epics represent larger bodies of work that contain multiple child issues. Mixing them with regular issues in the same table creates noise and makes it difficult to:
- Track high-level progress on major initiatives
- Understand how much work remains within each epic
- Distinguish between actionable tasks and container/tracking issues
- Navigate the work hierarchy effectively

A dedicated epics view provides focus for planning and progress tracking at the initiative level.

**Usage Examples:**
1. Product owner opens the Epics view to see all major initiatives and their completion status at a glance
2. Team lead notices "Authentication Rewrite" epic shows "3/12 open" and drills in to understand remaining work
3. During quarterly planning, stakeholders review the Epics table to assess initiative progress
4. Developer filters main issues table without epic clutter, seeing only actionable work items

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Create `EpicsTable` component displaying only issues where `issue_type === 'epic'`
- Modify existing `AllIssuesTable` to exclude epics (`issue_type !== 'epic'`)
- Add new column "Child Count" to EpicsTable showing: `{open_children} / {total_children}`
  - `open_children`: count of associated issues NOT in closed/done/tombstone status
  - `total_children`: count of all associated issues regardless of status
  - Association determined by child issues having `parent_id` matching epic's `id`, or epic's `id` in child's `dependencies` array
- Child count should be clickable to filter main issues table to that epic's children
- Include all standard table columns: ID, Title, Status, Priority, Assignee, Created, Updated
- Support existing table functionality: sorting, filtering, row selection
- Add navigation/tab to switch between "Issues" and "Epics" views
- Consider visual treatment to distinguish epic rows (subtle background or icon)

**Required Unit Tests:**
- EpicsTable renders only issues with `issue_type === 'epic'`
- AllIssuesTable excludes issues with `issue_type === 'epic'`
- Child count correctly counts total associated issues
- Child count correctly counts open (non-closed) associated issues
- Child count displays in format "X / Y" (open / total)
- Child count handles epics with zero children (displays "0 / 0")

title: Export to CSV/JSON
description:
Implement data export functionality allowing users to download the current filtered dataset as CSV or JSON files, including both raw issue data and calculated metrics.

**Why it's needed:**
The dashboard provides excellent visualization but teams often need:
- Data for offline analysis in Excel or Google Sheets
- Raw data for custom scripts or tooling
- Shareable reports for stakeholders without dashboard access
- Archival of point-in-time snapshots
- Integration with other reporting tools

Export removes the dashboard as a bottleneck for data access.

**Usage Examples:**
1. Manager exports last month's completed issues as CSV for executive report
2. Developer exports JSON to pipe into custom analysis script
3. Team exports current sprint data for offline retrospective analysis
4. Analyst exports metrics summary for quarterly review deck

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Create `ExportButton` component with format selection dropdown
- Export formats: CSV, JSON
- Create export functions for issue data
- CSV: flattened structure, headers as first row, proper escaping
- JSON: array of issue objects with full detail
- Respect current filters (date range, assignee, status, etc.)
- Include option to export calculated fields (cycle time, age)
- Create export for metrics summary
- Throughput (daily/weekly counts)
- Cycle time statistics (average, P50, P85, P95)
- Current WIP counts by status
- Filename includes export date and filter description
- Large dataset handling (streaming or chunking if needed)
- Trigger browser download (no server round-trip)

**Required Unit Tests:**
- CSV export generates valid CSV format
- CSV export includes all visible columns
- CSV export properly escapes commas, quotes, newlines
- JSON export generates valid JSON format
- JSON export includes all issue fields
- Export respects active filters
- Export includes only filtered issues, not all issues
- Calculated fields (cycle time, age) included when option selected
- Metrics export generates correct summary statistics
- Filename generated with correct date and descriptors
- Empty filtered result produces valid empty file with headers
design:
**Export Button:**
- Position: dashboard header, near filter controls
- Button with dropdown: "Export ‚ñº"
- Dropdown options: "Issues as CSV", "Issues as JSON", "Metrics Summary"
- Checkbox option: "Include calculated fields" (cycle time, age)

**Export Progress:**
- For large datasets, show progress indicator
- "Preparing export..." state with spinner
- Browser download triggered automatically when ready

**File Naming:**
- Pattern: `beads-export-{type}-{date}-{filter-summary}.{ext}`
- Examples: `beads-export-issues-2024-01-15-last-30-days.csv`
- `beads-export-metrics-2024-01-15.json`

**Metrics Summary Content:**
- Date range of analysis
- Total issues in range
- Throughput: total, average per day/week
- Cycle time: min, max, average, P50, P85, P95
- Current WIP by status
- Export timestamp
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] User can export filtered issue data as CSV file
- [ ] User can export filtered issue data as JSON file
- [ ] Exported data respects all active filters (date range, assignee, status, etc.)
- [ ] Export includes option for calculated fields (cycle time, age)
- [ ] User can export a metrics summary (throughput, cycle times, WIP counts)
- [ ] Exported files have descriptive names including date and filter context

title: Kanban Board View
description:
Implement a drag-and-drop Kanban board view that displays work items as cards organized into columns based on their workflow status (open, in_progress, blocked, done, etc.). The board should provide at-a-glance visibility into the state of work across multiple coding agents.

**Why it's needed:**
The current table view is excellent for data analysis but doesn't provide the spatial, real-time workflow visibility that engineers need when supervising multiple coding agents. A Kanban board is essential for agent oversight because:
- Engineers can instantly see what each agent is working on and identify stuck agents without reading through logs
- Visual clustering reveals when too many tasks are piling up in a particular state (e.g., multiple agents blocked waiting for review)
- Quick intervention is possible‚Äîdragging a stuck task back to "Open" to reassign it to a different agent takes one gesture
- WIP limits per column help engineers avoid overloading the system with too many concurrent agent tasks
- The spatial layout maps naturally to the mental model of "agents working in parallel on different tasks"

When managing 3-5+ coding agents simultaneously, a table requires cognitive effort to parse. A board lets you pattern-match instantly: "Two cards in Blocked, five in Progress, one aging red‚ÄîI need to check on that blocked work."

**Usage Examples:**
1. Engineer starts their day, opens the Board view, and immediately sees one agent's task has been "In Progress" for 6 hours (red age badge)‚Äîinvestigates and finds the agent stuck in a loop
2. During async check-in, engineer glances at board and sees healthy flow: cards moving steadily from Open ‚Üí In Progress ‚Üí Done
3. Engineer spots an agent has 3 cards in "In Progress" simultaneously (violating single-task focus), investigates the agent's configuration
4. WIP limit indicator shows "In Progress: 5/5"‚Äîengineer knows not to assign new work until agents complete current tasks
5. Engineer filters board to single agent's work to review that agent's throughput and identify if it's consistently slower than others

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Create a new `KanbanBoard` component that fetches issues grouped by status
- Each column represents a workflow status from the Beads schema (open, in_progress, blocked, deferred, done, tombstone)
- Cards display: title, issue ID, priority indicator, assignee (agent name or human), age badge (colored by aging rules‚Äîhours for agents, days for humans)
- Assignee display should distinguish agents from humans visually (e.g., robot icon vs avatar, or configurable agent name patterns)
- Drag-and-drop functionality updates the issue status via the Beads API
- Column headers show: status name, card count, WIP limit indicator (if configured)
- Cards should be clickable to open issue details (reuse existing detail view)
- Support filtering board by assignee to focus on single agent's work
- Support touch devices for drag operations
- Persist view preference (table vs board) in localStorage
- Consider "swim lanes" by assignee as a future enhancement for multi-agent visibility

**Required Unit Tests:**
- `KanbanBoard` renders correct number of columns for all workflow statuses
- Issues are correctly grouped into their respective status columns
- Dragging a card between columns triggers status update API call with correct parameters
- Card displays all required fields (title, ID, priority, assignee, age)
- Assignee field correctly identifies and displays agent vs human assignees
- Age badge color matches aging rules (hour-based thresholds: green < 2h, orange < 4h, red > 4h for agent work)
- Age badge displays appropriate time format (hours/minutes for recent, days for older)
- Empty columns render with appropriate empty state
- WIP count updates immediately after drag operation (optimistic update)
- WIP limit warning displays when column count meets or exceeds limit
- Failed drag operation reverts card to original column and shows error
- Filtering by assignee shows only that assignee's cards
- Board correctly updates in real-time when underlying data changes (agent completes work)
design:
**Layout:**
- Horizontal scrolling container with fixed-width columns (280-320px)
- Columns ordered by workflow progression: Open ‚Üí In Progress ‚Üí Blocked ‚Üí Done ‚Üí Deferred ‚Üí Tombstone
- Sticky column headers that remain visible when scrolling vertically within a column

**Card Design:**
- Compact card height (~80-100px) to maximize visible cards
- Visual hierarchy: Title (bold, truncate with ellipsis) > ID + Priority > Assignee + Age
- Priority indicator: colored left border or badge (P0=red, P1=orange, P2=yellow, P3=blue, P4=gray)
- Subtle shadow on hover, elevated shadow while dragging
- Drop zone highlight when dragging over valid columns

**Interactions:**
- Cursor changes to grab on card hover, grabbing while dragging
- Semi-transparent ghost card follows cursor during drag
- Invalid drop zones (if any) show visual rejection indicator
- Smooth animation when cards reorder within columns

**Responsive Behavior:**
- On narrow screens (<768px), show horizontal scroll with snap points
- Consider a mobile-optimized single-column view with status tabs
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] User can view all issues organized into columns by workflow status
- [ ] User can drag a card from one column to another and the issue status updates in the database
- [ ] Cards display title, ID, priority, and color-coded age indicator
- [ ] Assignee is displayed with visual distinction between agents and human users
- [ ] Column shows accurate card count and WIP limit warning if limit exceeded
- [ ] Board view persists as user preference when switching away and returning
- [ ] Drag and drop works on both mouse and touch devices
close_reason: Feature complete and merged to main. Implemented full Kanban board with drag-and-drop, all acceptance criteria met.

title: Quick Filters (Faceted Navigation)
description:
Implement a sidebar with one-click filter buttons/chips for common issue attributes: Assignee, Priority, Issue Type, and Labels. Filters should be combinable and instantly update all dashboard views.

**Why it's needed:**
Currently, users must manually search or scan through all issues to find specific subsets. This is time-consuming and error-prone, especially as the issue count grows. Quick filters provide:
- Instant access to common queries ("show me my P1 bugs")
- Discoverable filtering without learning search syntax
- Visual indication of active filters
- Combinable filters for complex queries (Assignee=me AND Priority=1 AND Type=bug)

**Usage Examples:**
1. Developer clicks their name in the Assignee filter to see only their assigned work
2. QA engineer combines Type=bug + Priority=0 to focus on critical bugs
3. Team lead clicks "In Progress" status + "Blocked" to find stuck work
4. User clicks a label "frontend" to see all frontend-related issues

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Create `FilterSidebar` component with collapsible sections for each facet
- Facet sections: Status, Assignee, Priority (0-4), Type (bug, feature, task, chore), Labels
- Each facet shows available values with issue counts (e.g., "Alice (5)", "Bug (12)")
- Clicking a value toggles it as an active filter
- Multiple selections within a facet use OR logic (Priority 1 OR 2)
- Selections across facets use AND logic (Priority 1 AND Type=bug)
- Active filters shown as removable chips above the main content
- "Clear all filters" button when any filter is active
- Filter state syncs to URL query parameters (for shareability)
- Filters apply to all views: Table, Charts, and Kanban board

**Required Unit Tests:**
- `FilterSidebar` renders all facet sections with correct values from data
- Facet values show accurate issue counts
- Clicking a filter value adds it to active filters
- Clicking an active filter value removes it
- Multiple filters within same facet combine with OR logic
- Filters across different facets combine with AND logic
- Active filter chips render correctly and are removable
- "Clear all" button resets all filters
- URL updates when filters change
- Page load with filter query params applies filters correctly
- Filtered data propagates to table view correctly
- Filtered data propagates to chart components correctly
design:
**Layout:**
- Left sidebar, 240-280px width, collapsible to icon-only (48px) on user toggle
- Each facet section has header with expand/collapse chevron
- Facet values as list items or horizontal chip groups depending on count

**Visual Design:**
- Active filters highlighted with primary color background
- Count badges right-aligned, muted color
- Facet sections with subtle separators
- "Clear all" link/button in filters header area

**Active Filter Chips:**
- Horizontal row above main content area
- Each chip shows "Facet: Value" with X to remove
- Chips wrap to multiple lines if many active

**States:**
- Empty facet (no values): hide section or show "None" disabled
- Zero-count values: show but visually muted, still clickable
- Loading state: skeleton loaders for counts during data fetch

**Responsive:**
- On mobile, filters collapse to a modal/drawer triggered by filter icon button
- Filter chips remain visible in a horizontally scrollable row
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Sidebar displays filter options for Status, Assignee, Priority, Type, and Labels
- [ ] Each filter option shows the count of matching issues
- [ ] Clicking a filter immediately updates the displayed issues in all views
- [ ] Multiple filters can be combined (AND across facets, OR within facets)
- [ ] Active filters are displayed as removable chips
- [ ] Filter state is reflected in the URL and shareable via link
- [ ] Filters persist when switching between Table, Board, and Chart views

title: Aging WIP Alerts and Thresholds
description:
Implement a configurable alert system that highlights work items exceeding age thresholds, with prominent dashboard placement and proactive notifications for at-risk items. Thresholds should support both hour-based and day-based granularity to accommodate fast-moving agent workflows.

**Why it's needed:**
The existing Aging WIP scatterplot shows item ages with color coding, but engineers overseeing coding agents need:
- Fine-grained thresholds in hours (4h, 8h, 24h) because agents can complete many tasks within a single workday
- Early warning when an agent's task is taking longer than expected‚Äîoften a sign the agent is stuck, looping, or blocked
- A dedicated view for items needing human intervention so engineers can quickly identify where to step in
- Visual prominence so stalled agent work doesn't silently accumulate while the engineer focuses elsewhere

When supervising multiple coding agents, a task aging beyond expected bounds is a critical signal. It often means the agent has hit an edge case, is waiting on input, or has encountered an error state. Traditional day-based thresholds (7/30 days) are far too slow‚Äîby the time a task is days old in an agent workflow, significant time and compute have been wasted.

**Usage Examples:**
1. Engineer configures thresholds: warning at 4 hours, critical at 8 hours for agent-assigned tasks
2. Dashboard header shows badge: "2 items critical, 5 items warning"‚Äîengineer immediately knows agents need attention
3. Engineer sees an agent's task highlighted red after 6 hours, investigates and finds the agent stuck in a retry loop
4. During daily review, engineer scans the aging alert list and reassigns a stuck task to a different agent or takes it over manually
5. Team uses different thresholds for agent work (hours) vs human work (days) based on assignee type
6. Engineer spots a pattern: tasks involving legacy API consistently age out, indicating a systemic blocker to address

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Create `AgingThresholdConfig` component for setting thresholds
- Thresholds support both hours and days with unit selector (e.g., "4 hours" or "2 days")
- Granularity options: 1h, 2h, 4h, 8h, 12h, 24h, and custom day values
- Configurable "warning" and "critical" thresholds (defaults: 4 hours and 8 hours for agent context)
- Option to set different thresholds by assignee type (agent vs human) or label
- Option to auto-calculate from percentiles (e.g., P85 and P95 of historical cycle time)
- Store configuration in localStorage
- Create `AgingAlertBadge` component for dashboard header showing count of items at each level
- Create `AgingAlertList` component showing all items exceeding warning threshold
- List sorted by age (oldest first), shows: title, ID, age (in appropriate units), assignee, status
- Age display adapts to magnitude: "3h 24m" for recent, "2.5 days" for older items
- Integrate aging indicators into Table View rows and Kanban cards
- Row/card background tint or border color based on aging status
- Filter quick-action to show only aging items
- Optional: filter to show only agent-assigned aging items vs human-assigned

**Required Unit Tests:**
- Threshold configuration saves and loads correctly with hour-based values
- Threshold configuration saves and loads correctly with day-based values
- Hour-to-millisecond conversion calculates correctly for comparisons
- Items correctly classified: normal (below warning), warning (between warning and critical), critical (above critical)
- Classification works correctly for hour-based thresholds (e.g., 4h warning, 8h critical)
- Classification works correctly for day-based thresholds
- Auto-calculate from percentiles returns correct threshold values
- Alert badge shows correct counts for each level
- Alert list includes all items above warning threshold
- Alert list sorted by age descending (oldest first)
- Age display shows hours/minutes for items under 24 hours
- Age display shows days for items over 24 hours
- Table row styling applies correct class based on aging status
- Kanban card styling applies correct class based on aging status
- Items at exactly threshold boundary classified correctly
- Aging calculations use correct date field (created_at or status change)
- Different thresholds per assignee type applies correctly (if implemented)
design:
**Configuration Panel:**
- Accessible from settings/gear icon
- Threshold inputs: Warning and Critical values
- Unit selector: 'Hours' or 'Days' for each threshold (or global toggle)
- Toggle for 'Auto-calculate from historical data' with percentile dropdowns
- Preview showing how many current items fall into each bucket

**Alert Badge (Header):**
- Position: dashboard header, right side near notifications
- Compact display: icon + count, expandable on click
- Color-coded: yellow background for warnings only, red if any critical
- Click expands to dropdown list of affected items

**Aging Alert List:**
- Dedicated section or tab in dashboard
- Table format: Issue, Age, Threshold Status, Assignee, Status
- Row backgrounds: light yellow (warning), light red (critical)
- 'Age' column shows both value and relative description ('12h - critical' or '3 days - warning')

**Table/Card Integration:**
- Subtle left border or background tint (not overwhelming)
- Warning: soft yellow/amber tint
- Critical: soft red/pink tint
- Consistent colors across Table, Board, and Alert views
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] User can configure warning and critical age thresholds in either hours or days
- [ ] Dashboard header displays count of items in warning and critical states
- [ ] Dedicated view/list shows all aging items sorted by age
- [ ] Table view rows are visually highlighted based on aging status
- [ ] Kanban board cards are visually highlighted based on aging status
- [ ] Threshold configuration persists across sessions

title: Quick Change Priority
description:
Add inline priority adjustment controls (up/down arrows) next to the priority badge in the issues table, allowing users to quickly increment or decrement an issue's priority without opening a modal or detail view.

**Why it's needed:**
Priority adjustments are one of the most common actions during backlog grooming and triage. Currently, changing priority requires:
1. Opening the issue detail view
2. Finding the priority field
3. Selecting a new value
4. Saving and closing

This friction discourages quick prioritization decisions. Inline controls enable:
- Rapid triage during review sessions
- Easy reordering during standups
- Quick adjustments as priorities shift
- Efficient bulk-style prioritization without formal bulk actions

**Usage Examples:**
1. During triage, product owner rapidly promotes several bugs from P3 to P2 using up arrows
2. Developer demotes a P1 feature to P2 as more urgent work arrives‚Äîsingle click
3. Team reviews table sorted by priority and adjusts outliers inline during grooming
4. New urgent issue arrives; user quickly promotes it to P0 with two up-arrow clicks

**Implementation Requirements:**
- Add `PriorityQuickChange` component to priority cell in issues table
- Display current priority badge with up/down arrow buttons flanking it
- Up arrow: decreases priority number (higher priority: P3 ‚Üí P2 ‚Üí P1 ‚Üí P0)
- Down arrow: increases priority number (lower priority: P0 ‚Üí P1 ‚Üí P2 ‚Üí P3 ‚Üí P4)
- Disable up arrow when priority is already P0 (highest)
- Disable down arrow when priority is already P4 (lowest)
- Click triggers immediate API update (optimistic update pattern)
- Visual feedback during save (subtle loading state or brief highlight)
- Error handling: revert to original value and show error toast on failure
- Arrows visible on row hover only (to reduce visual noise) OR always visible (configurable)
- Keyboard support: when row/cell focused, up/down arrow keys adjust priority
- Ensure click targets are large enough for reliable clicking (min 24x24px)

**Required Unit Tests:**
- Up arrow decreases priority value (P3 ‚Üí P2)
- Down arrow increases priority value (P2 ‚Üí P3)
- Up arrow disabled when priority is P0
- Down arrow disabled when priority is P4
- Click triggers API update with correct new priority value
- Optimistic update shows new priority immediately
- Failed update reverts priority and shows error
- Arrows appear on row hover (if hover-only mode)
- Keyboard up arrow decreases priority when cell focused
- Keyboard down arrow increases priority when cell focused
- Priority badge updates to reflect new value and color
- Rapid clicks are debounced or queued appropriately
design:
**Layout:**
- Priority cell contains: [‚Üë] [Priority Badge] [‚Üì]
- Arrows positioned immediately adjacent to badge
- Compact spacing to fit within table cell without expanding column width

**Arrow Buttons:**
- Small, subtle arrow icons (chevron-up, chevron-down)
- Size: 20-24px clickable area, icon itself ~12-14px
- Default state: muted/gray color
- Hover state: primary color, slight scale or background
- Disabled state: very muted, cursor not-allowed, no hover effect
- Active/click state: brief press effect

**Visibility Options:**
- Option A (Hover): arrows invisible by default, appear on row hover
  - Cleaner table appearance, less visual noise
  - May be less discoverable
- Option B (Always): arrows always visible but very subtle
  - More discoverable, consistent muscle memory
  - Slightly busier table appearance
- Recommend starting with hover-reveal, making it configurable later

**Priority Badge:**
- Existing badge design (colored by priority level)
- Badge should remain clickable to open full edit (if that exists)
- Or badge click could cycle priority (alternative to arrows)

**Feedback States:**
- Saving: brief opacity reduction or spinner overlay on badge
- Success: subtle flash/highlight (green tint, 200ms)
- Error: shake animation + red flash + error toast

**Keyboard Interaction:**
- Tab navigates to priority cell
- Up/Down arrow keys adjust priority
- Visual focus indicator on cell when keyboard-focused
- Arrow buttons themselves not in tab order (arrows are mouse/touch convenience)

**Responsive:**
- On touch devices, arrows should always be visible (no hover)
- Ensure touch targets meet minimum size (44x44px recommended for mobile)
- Consider swipe gestures as alternative on mobile (swipe right = promote, left = demote)
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Up and down arrow buttons appear next to the priority badge in table rows
- [ ] Clicking up arrow increases priority (lower number, e.g., P3 ‚Üí P2)
- [ ] Clicking down arrow decreases priority (higher number, e.g., P2 ‚Üí P3)
- [ ] Up arrow is disabled when issue is already highest priority (P0)
- [ ] Down arrow is disabled when issue is already lowest priority (P4)
- [ ] Priority changes are saved immediately without requiring a modal or confirmation
- [ ] Visual feedback confirms the save (or shows error if save fails)

title: Refactor Components
description:
# Refactor Core UI & Business‚ÄëLogic Components to Align with the New Design System and Improve Extensibility

## Background / Context

- Recent design updates (color palette, typography scale, iconography) demand a **consistent visual language** throughout every interactive piece.
- New feature work (e.g., dynamic dashboards, adaptive forms) will require reusable, composable pieces that are easier to test and extend.

## Deliverables
- Updated component files with lint‚Äëfree, type‚Äëchecked code.
- New/updated Storybook entries showcasing each refactored component in isolation & in context.
- One pull request per sub‚Äëmodule (e.g., `UserCard`, `AnalyticsChart`, `FilterBar`) that passes CI on all browsers (Chrome, Safari, Edge).
- Updated CI workflows to enforce new styling rules (`eslint-plugin-design-system` and `prettier-config`).
